stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on the visual development of the overworld, specifically creating and applying textures and N64 'combiner' shaders to areas around the Bunny Burrow entrance, a cave, and a lighthouse. The stream heavily featured his iterative creative process, his design philosophies of making the world feel 'placey', and technical problem-solving within the N64's limitations.

development_findings.summary: A core design principle for the overworld is to make it feel like a real, cohesive 'place' rather than a functional, 'gamey' level hub.
development_findings.quote: That makes the overworld feel very gamey and I want this to feel placey.

development_findings.summary: The project is being developed with a strict technical constraint of fitting the final ROM within the standard 64-megabyte N64 cartridge size, rejecting the use of larger custom cartridges.
development_findings.quote: I limited myself to exactly 64 megabytes.

development_findings.summary: A user-friendly cutscene skip mechanic is being implemented where holding the 'A' button for 30 frames fills a meter and immediately ends the cinematic.
development_findings.quote: The cutscene just stops, and you're right in the action.

development_findings.summary: The Pachyderm character, who blocks an entrance, will feature a player-choice interaction inspired by Yoshi's Story, allowing progress via payment or a specific gameplay action.
development_findings.quote: You can either pay him 10 coins, or you can do a ground pound next to him, just like in Yoshi's Story, which will flip him over.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is highly critical of the original Mario 64 source code, citing the shadow rendering and Dire Dire Docks submarine code as examples of inefficient programming that caused significant performance issues.
development_findings.quote: I would say that the code I've seen in Mario 64 is below average, unfortunately.

development_findings.summary: A recurring technical challenge is a bug in the Fast64 Blender plugin where texture previews do not match the in-game render due to incorrect alpha handling, forcing Kaze to debug issues directly on hardware/emulator.
Kaze believes his development pace is faster than the original SM64 team's, even considering his disadvantages like working part-time and advantages like modern tools.
development_findings.quote: I think when you take combined time into account, I will have spent less time on Rty than Mario 64 team has spent on Mario 64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is open to the idea of a Gamecube port of the game, but only if it becomes possible through the decompilation project's efforts without requiring a full rewrite.
development_findings.quote: The only parts that so far I am interested in giving an attempt is anything Recomp can do. So if the Recomp can target Gamecube, then yes, I am interested.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong philosophical stance that genuine belief must be backed by significant personal investment, applying this logic to stock market predictions.
context_findings.quote: If you make a prediction for the future, and you are 100% certain of it, and you are not invested into this prediction with 100% of your money, then you are lying.

context_findings.summary: Kaze balances the development of RTYI with a full-time job as an Unreal Engine 5 game developer, YouTube content creation, and family life with a child.
context_findings.quote: I do have a full-time job outside of making this game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze assesses his own abilities as having high practical skill but a narrower knowledge base due to being self-taught, which he contrasts with the original Mario 64 developers.
context_findings.quote: I do think, skill-wise, I'm at least a top 2% or 3% programmer. Knowledge-wise, probably not. And it is because I never formally learned programming.

context_findings.summary: Kaze understands the modern game development trade-off where developers sacrifice optimization for increased development speed and scope, enabled by more powerful hardware.
context_findings.quote: Now that we don't have to care about optimization anymore, we can make games faster. Isn't that cool?

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed significant frustration with the Stack Overflow community culture, recounting instances where his specific, advanced questions were dismissed by moderators as pointless.
To increase his video output, Kaze hired an editor and a sponsorship agency, pragmatically accepting the resulting commercialization of his channel as a necessary trade-off.
context_findings.quote: I had to get an agency to find sponsors for me, so that I can pay the editing. And now I actually make way more money from YouTube videos... But it has kind of commercialized my YouTube channel.

biobak.summary: The team's visual workflow involves Kaze creating placeholder art and shaders, which Biobak then reworks and polishes for the final game.
biobak.quote: Our goal here is to throw together some shaders that work well, and put some ideas into here. So if it's not perfect for now, that is fine... so that Biobak can actually make this look really good in the end.

biobak.summary: Biobak contributes to asset discovery and review, sometimes finding details in textures that Kaze had missed.
biobak.quote: Biobak showed this to me just recently, it has eyes? there were eyes in the texture? oops

zeina.summary: Zeina is involved in programming gameplay features, such as implementing a function to skip cutscenes.
zeina.quote: Zeina did you end up making the skip button?

zeina.summary: Kaze mentioned playing Minecraft with his wife, indicating a personal dynamic that coexists with their professional collaboration on the game.

key_stories.title: Crafting the Inviting Entrance
key_stories.summary: To enhance a gameplay scenario, Kaze needed to make a level entrance feel welcoming. He undertook an iterative technical and artistic process, fighting with N64 hardware limitations to craft a flower-adorned burrow that would motivate players to get past the guard.
key_stories.challenge: The entrance to the 'Bunny Burrow' level was visually uninteresting and needed to feel welcoming to create a narrative contrast with the character blocking it.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed using plants, reviewed concept art, and selected textures. He then iteratively worked with the N64's complex combiner (shader) system to layer flower decals over a vine texture and properly blend it with the cave entrance.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a distinct, inviting entrance with flowers and vines that fade into the darkness, enhancing the player's motivation to bypass the Pachyderm character.
key_stories.key_quote: We want the player to feel invited, that makes the guy blocking the entrance even better. Because then it's like, they want me to go here, but this asshole won't let me.

key_stories.title: The Compiler and the Community
key_stories.summary: When faced with a highly specific compiler optimization problem, Kaze was stonewalled by the online developer community. This experience highlights the frustration experts face when seeking help for niche issues and solidified his self-reliant approach to problem-solving.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted to force the GCC compiler to use a specific instruction for a niche optimization (prioritizing data throughput over cycle speed), but the compiler's default behavior and community forums were unhelpful.
key_stories.process: Kaze attempted to solve the issue by asking for help on Stack Overflow and the GCC forums. His questions were dismissed by moderators who didn't understand the specific context of his problem.
key_stories.outcome: He was unable to get help from the community, reinforcing his view of Stack Overflow as unhelpful for expert-level problems and forcing him to rely on his own solutions like inline assembly.
key_stories.key_quote: The compiler knows better than you, topic closed... you guys have no idea what you're talking about.

key_stories.title: The YouTube Production Engine
key_stories.summary: To overcome his time constraints, Kaze effectively built a small business around his YouTube channel. By hiring an editor and an agency to find sponsors, he created a self-sustaining content engine, demonstrating a pragmatic approach to balancing passion, time, and finances.
key_stories.challenge: Limited time due to a full-time job and family was preventing Kaze from producing as many YouTube videos as he wanted.
key_stories.process: To solve the time bottleneck, Kaze created a system: he hired a video editor to save time, and then hired a sponsorship agency to generate the revenue needed to pay the editor.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully increased his video output and income, but acknowledges it came at the cost of his channel becoming more commercialized, a trade-off he pragmatically accepted.
key_stories.key_quote: I had to get an agency to find sponsors for me, so that I can pay the editing. And now I actually make way more money from YouTube videos... But it has kind of commercialized my YouTube channel.

open_questions.context: Kaze frequently mentions that he creates 'first pass' or placeholder art and that Biobak, the team's artist, will 'rework it' or 'make it look good'.
questions: Can you walk me through the typical workflow when handing off a level from your initial design to Biobak for artistic refinement?
How do you communicate the intended mood and style?
How much creative freedom does Biobak have to alter your original concepts?
Could you share an example where Biobak's final art surprised you or took the level in a new direction?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that the game's overworld is guided by a design philosophy of feeling 'placey' not 'gamey' and that a design document exists with plans to make it feel 'alive'.
questions: What are the core pillars of your 'placey' design philosophy for the overworld?
Besides having characters appear, what other specific plans are in the design document to make the world feel alive and lived-in?
How has this design document evolved from the beginning of the project?

open_questions.topic: Balancing a Day Job (Unreal Engine) and a Passion Project (N64)
open_questions.context: Kaze revealed he has a full-time job developing games in Unreal Engine 5, a modern and powerful engine, while RTYI is built on a 30-year-old, highly constrained platform.
questions: How do you mentally switch between the world of Unreal Engine and the N64?
Does your professional work ever influence your design decisions on RTYI, perhaps by showing you what you want to avoid?
In what ways does working within the N64's limitations provide a creative satisfaction that modern engines might not?
How do you manage to avoid burnout while working on games both professionally and as a hobby?

open_questions.topic: Zeina's Role and the Personal/Professional Dynamic
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that his wife, Zeina, is an animator and is working on features like the cutscene skip button.
questions: Beyond animation and the skip button, what other areas of development is Zeina involved in?
How do you two navigate the dynamic of being life partners and close creative collaborators?
What is your process for resolving creative or technical disagreements on the project?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly mentioned the idea of buying Mario 64 sound samples to legally sell the RTYI soundtrack and the need to consult a copyright lawyer.
questions: What are the biggest legal concerns you face when creating a high-profile fan project like this?
How serious is the plan to commercialize the soundtrack, and what would that process look like?
What are your thoughts on the long-term future and legality of large-scale ROM hacks and decompilation-based games?
